dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in an important new article, University of Cambridge economist José Gabriel Palma argues that national income distributions are the result not of impersonal global forces, but rather of policy choices that reflect the control and lobbying power of the rich.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Changes in aggregate income distribution, therefore, resulted largely from changes in the respective shares of the top 10% and the bottom 40% of the population (the ratio between these shares is now called the Palma ratio). In other words, the huge variation in inequality across countries, and particularly between middle-income economies, is essentially the outcome of a fight for around one-half of national income involving one-half of the population.

dialogue_turns.text: But then in rich countries, even though middle-income shares have dropped, living standards rose because of falling costs for essentials like housing and healthcare.

dialogue_turns.text: And meanwhile, emerging economies are using fiscal measures to reduce market inequality—nationalization, regulating stock buybacks, higher top tax rates.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Specifically, this increase in value extraction is the result of policies for which the rich have actively lobbied: privatization; deregulation of share buybacks that artificially inflate stock prices; patent laws that make drugs much more expensive; reduction or elimination of top marginal tax rates; and much else.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But the article warns that if governments don't channel private capital better—like through a Global Green New Deal—this trend could threaten democracy itself.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This trend not only magnifies the risk of economic stagnation and market failures; political changes around the world suggest that it has also become a profound threat to democracy.
